newsitem.title: UK: U.S. auto, tech stocks lower in London trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. auto, tech stocks lower in London trade.

text.p: U.S. auto and technology stocks were quoted lower in London trading on Tuesday, pointing to a weaker opening on Wall Street, dealers said.
"With those two sectors under pressure we would be looking for a slightly lower start on the Street," one said.
A two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee (FOMC), due to get under way later on Tuesday, was not expected to raise interest rates.
Yet markets were seen continuing cautious ahead of Thursday's U.S. jobs report, which will give an indication of the pace of growth in the economy in the past month.

Amid talk of weak used-car prices and rising consumer debt levels, General Motors, Chrysler and Ford shares all dipped as a report in the Wall Street Journal said they were expected to post weak sales for the month of June.
GM was down $3/8 at $55-1/4, Chrysler was down $3/8 at $32-3/8 and Ford nudged $1/8 lower at $37-5/8.

Separately, a warning from chipmaker Cyrix that it expected to post a loss in the second quarter, due to weak demand and pricing pressures from its older-generation microprocessors, depressed other leading technology stocks.
Intel was down $1/2 at $141-1/8, Motorola dipped $1/4 to $75-3/4 and International Business Machines (IBM) was quoted $1/4 lower at $90.
Also in the technology sector, Microsoft was down $1/2 at $125-7/8 after a press report of a possible bid for broadcaster CBS, owned by Westinghouse which was up $1/4 at $23-3/8, dealers said.
Elsewhwere most of the interest focused on Office Depot and Staples after a judge's decision to grant a preliminary injunction to their $4 billion merger, first announced last September.
Dealers said both stocks were expected to come under pressure since the two were expected to abandon the merger plan.

U.S. economic reports later on Tuesday include the National Association of Purchasing Managers report for June, expected to show a drop in the purchasing managers' index to 56.4 from 57.1 a month before.
Other indicators include construction spending and lead indicators for May.
Yet investors were seen more likely to be waiting for Thursday's nonfarm payrolls -- brought forward from thier usual Friday release because of the Independence Day public holiday.
Recent economic reports have almost unanimously suggested a cooling in the pace of growth and slack inflation pressures. The payroll report will be closely scrutinised for confirmation of this trend.
S&P 500 June futures were trading down 6.25 points at 920.35 by 1105 GMT, after the S&P 500 index on Monday fell 2.16 points to 885.14.
September futures on the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond were up 1/32 at 111-3/32. At Monday's close the benchmark long bond was yielding 6.8 percent.
